I'd like to (tentatively) suggest that religiosity is more fundamental that theism. Yi-Fu Tuan, in an article titled "Humanistic Geography" appearing in the Annals of the Association of American Geographers, Vol. 66, No. 2: 266-276, defines religion asthe impulse for cohesion and meaning.I see no requirement that meaning come from superstition rather than science and, therefore, no barrier to a religious humanism predicated upon methodological naturalism. Thoughts?

I think of religion as a culture in which the members follow certain limitations placed on themselves, limitations that are asid to derive from some higher uncomprehendable power or authority.
wilted_laughter

I think religion provides the illusion of moral authority in an orderless world, alleviates the fear of death and provides comfort in the face of adversity.
 
 Thats why I don't believe, it's too easy. (Other than the fact that there are countless religions and there's no reason to believe in one over any other).
 
 Not that I'm saying religion doesn't play an important role in human society.
johnhanks

I think religion provides the illusion of moral authority in an orderless world, alleviates the fear of death and provides comfort in the face of adversity.
 
 Thats why I don't believe, it's too easy. (Other than the fact that there are countless religions and there's no reason to believe in one over any other).
 
 Not that I'm saying religion doesn't play an important role in human society.

 
 'Illusion of moral authority' is a good phrase. One of religion's prime adaptive functions for a society has always been to provide the moral underpinning for whatever obligations and proscriptions are expedient for that society at a given point in its history. At a trivial level we see this in the Old Testament food taboos (imposed in a society where pig-keeping, for example, would have been economically and ecologically unsustainable) being relaxed in the so-called 'new covenent'; less trivially we see it in the divinely sanctioned instances of what can only be called genocide in Numbers and Deuteronomy. Killing women and children was morally acceptable, apparently, if ordered by god.
trs

At a trivial level we see this in the Old Testament food taboos (imposed in a society where pig-keeping, for example, would have been economically and ecologically unsustainable) being relaxed in the so-called 'new covenent'; ...
How is pig unsustainable in small highland post-pastoral settlements that charactrized nascent Israel?
johnhanks

How is pig unsustainable in small highland post-pastoral settlements that charactrized nascent Israel?

 
 Ruminants like sheep and goats (both 'clean') are well able to digest coarse scrubby vegetation, and are efficient converters of cellulose into meat; pigs aren't cellulose digesters. And, though I don't pretend to any authority here, I doubt the pig taboo was restricted to 'nascent Israel', or that it appeared de novo in the post-pastoral era.
 
 Marvin Harris has written about this, but (dammit) I can't find the reference.

 The answers provided by that type of religion would be unsatisfactory to most, wouldn't you think?

Ruminants like sheep and goats (both 'clean') are well able to digest coarse scrubby vegetation, and are efficient converters of cellulose into meat; pigs aren't cellulose digesters.
Pigs don't graze. Therefore? 
 
 
Zooarchaeologists seemingly rescued the early Israelites from obscurity. The apparent abstinence from pork in fulfillment of the biblical injunction (Lev 11:7-8; Deut 14:8) was embraced as the elusive marker of Israelite ethnicity.28 Brian Hesse and Paula Wapnish tabulated percentages of pig bones among faunal collections from Israel, Syria, Iraq, eastern Anatolia, and Egypt, spanning the ninth to the first millennium.29Relevant to this discussion are their findings from second- and first-millennium Cisjordan. Their efforts are hamstrung by the small number of faunal assemblages analyzed, samples of widely varying size (from 47 to 3,950 bones), and the variability of intrasite distribution depending on context. Isolating the results of southern Levantine sites, five Middle Bronze Age sites demonstrated "intense exploitation" of pig, from 8 to 34 percent of identified animal bones in domestic debris. Late Bronze Age sites yielded "scant" Late Bronze Age evidence, with the sole highland site of Shiloh yielding a mere 0.17 percent (one bone). Pig was rare but present in Iron I highland sites: 0.7 percent at Shiloh, one bone each at Ai and Khirbet Raddana, and "some" from the City of David (none from the Ophel). By contrast, the pig samples of 18 and 19 percent respectively from Iron I Tel Miqne and Ashkelon constitute incontrovertible evidence of Iron I Philistine pork consumption. At all Philistine sites analyzed, Ashkelon, Tel Miqne, and Tell Batash, pig exploitation decreased through the centuries, beginning in the eleventh century B.C.E. Overall, Hesse and Wapnish's results demonstrate reliance on pig in the Middle Bronze Age, with greatly diminished use from the Late Bronze Age through the Persian period except for Iron I Philistia, with a return to pork as a dietary mainstay in the Hellenistic and later periods.30Based on these findings, those who seek to identify Israelites on the basis of abstinence from pork are hampered by the single Late Bronze Age highland site with a "trace" of pig, which precludes distinguishing the Iron I highland "Israelites" from their predecessors. 
 
 - see Journal of Biblical Literature: ISRAELITE ETHNICITY IN IRON I
I found the following interesting Q&A between the DanDiego Jewish Journal and Dever ...
 
 
Is there any evidence that these early Israelites followed a primitive form of kosher dietary laws?
 There is some. It's very striking that in the earliest settlements we have around 1200, there is statistically speaking no presence of pig bones. Almost zero percentage. Whereas in Canaanite or Philistine sites of the period, pork was widely consumed it seems. So the prohibition against pork seems to be a very early Israelite ethnic trait.... We don't understand the reason for it exactly... but it was probably a simple marker: the Canaanites do this, so we don't do it.
 
 -see [url=http://www.sdjewishjournal.com/stories/cover_jan04.html]Where did we come from?
Similarly ...
 
 
Professor Dever finds the earliest convergence between the Old Testament and the archaeological record in the 13th century B.C. At about that time, the population of the central hill country west of the Jordan River and south of the Sea of Galilee began to expand rapidly, rising an estimated five-fold in the course of a century. The settlements that provide evidence of this "population explosion" differ markedly from nearby Canaanite centers, with distinctive house styles and new technologies, such as intensive terracing and stone-lined grain silos. The most startling difference, though, is that pig bones, common in other areas, are almost completely absent. There is no zoological reason why the settlers should not have kept swine, and Professor Dever takes this apparent aversion as a marker of a "proto-Israelite" ethnic group. He adduces other parallels, too, between this archaeological assemblage and the society depicted in Judges and Samuel, as well as a small bit of confirmatory data from a non-Biblical text: A famous stele erected by the Egyptian pharaoh Merneptah in about 1210 B.C. describes a campaign against Canaan, mentioning a people called "Israel" among those defeated. The stele contains enough geographical information to make it likely that this "Israel" was located in the same area as the new hill country assemblage.
 - see  Stromata
That pig was widely consumed throughout the area argues against any economic/ecological unsustainability argument.
 
 
And, though I don't pretend to any authority here, I doubt the pig taboo was restricted to 'nascent Israel', or that it appeared de novo in the post-pastoral era.
Those are not the same: while few cultural markers appear entirely de novo, the archaeology suggests that the restriction was, in fact, diagnostic.
 
 If I had to hazard a guess (and that's all it would be), I would guess that the prohibition had far more to do with seeing the pig as a scavenger.

 OK, I'll concede on that. I suspect my Harris source is wildly out of date by now. I don't think my original premise (that religions function to give unquestionable underpinning to expedient and adaptive practices and institutions) is significantly affected.

No, but I find this definition (if suggested as such) to be faulty and a bit cynical. In its earliest instantiation there is little or no distinction between religion, science, and civil rule. Religion was (and for many, remains) inherently 'questioning'. Furthermore, what something is and how it comes to function are not the same thing: my car is not a ride to work.

 A red herring, I think. I made no attempt to define religion in terms of what adaptive advantages it brings to a society. To follow up your car analogy, we could no doubt quickly agree on a technical definition of what a car is; its owner might describe its functions purely in terms of transportation; but we might still impute to the ownership of certain models functions unacknowledged by the owner, such as status display.
 
 
In its earliest instantiation there is little or no distinction between religion, science, and civil rule.

 Please substantiate.
Alan Ryan

I think of religion as a culture in which the members follow certain limitations placed on themselves, limitations that are asid to derive from some higher uncomprehendable power or authority.

 
 I think you have drawn attention to a vital aspect of religion - namely its cohesive function in societies. The Latin root religare means "to bind" and traditionally a religion is what deeply binds a society. (Isn't there even a Christian hymn with words about "ties that bind" ?) 
 
 What all religions appear to have in common is an attitude of reverential wonder towards God (or the gods) accompanied by a belief system which affects basic patterns of individual and group behaviour. 
 
 Of course patterns of religious behaviour are immensely variable and culturally determined. To probe deeper, it would probably be necessary to specify the particular religion being discussed.
trs

I stand corrected.
